text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. text: Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

text: Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. text: Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed. Doctor: With prostate cancer also? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah. You’re one – Patient: Now, his scans came back --- bone scan and CAT scan came back, uh, uh, what do you call it? Negative. Positive? Nothing wrong which – Doctor: Now, remind me again, your children? How many children do you have? Patient: He is five years older.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
